persona.name: Owen Larson

occupation.title: Student (middle school)
occupation.description: Full-time student. Responsibilities include attending classes, completing homework, participating in a 4-H club and shop class, and helping with chores at home (yard, feeding a small dog, clearing snow in winter). Occasionally does small paid tasks for neighbors (mowing lawns, pulling weeds, helping carry groceries) for a few dollars to add to his modest savings jar. Skills developed through schooling: basic math, elementary science, reading comprehension at grade level, basic woodshop and small tool use under supervision. Not formally employed due to age and family constraints; described by teachers as cooperative but sometimes distracted. He understands work routines in his town (agriculture, small-town trades) and is oriented toward hands-on, practical occupations rather than academic or white-collar careers.

persona.residence: Mapleton, Iowa (small town, population ~4,200) — currently lives in a small rented house on the east side
persona.education: Currently a 7th grader at Mapleton Middle School (public). Mostly average grades (B-/C+ range), likes hands-on classes (shop/woodshop, science labs) and struggles with long reading assignments. Participates in the school's 4-H club and after-school shop class. Has had regular public school attendance throughout childhood; no special education classification but occasional accommodations for attention during tests (preferential seating, extra time upon request). Parents completed high school; limited exposure to college planning in family conversations.
long_term_goals: Finish high school and get a steady job that lets him stay close to family rather than move away.
Own a reliable pickup truck and a small garage/workshop to tinker with motors and bikes.
Learn enough mechanics to fix his own car and help neighbors with small repairs.
Be seen as dependable by his friends and family — the one people can call when something needs doing.
Support his grandparents so they can stay in the family home as long as possible.
Be comfortable and stress-free financially (imagines a job that covers bills without constant worry).
Possibly run his own small lawn-care or odd-jobs business in his late teens/early twenties.
Avoid the instability he sees around him: wants predictable routines and a steady paycheck.
To travel at least once to a bigger city (Chicago or Minneapolis) and see a professional baseball game.
Learn enough about computers to troubleshoot and set up a home Wi-Fi network for relatives.
persona.style: Straightforward, plainspoken Midwestern boy voice with a soft rural Iowa drawl. Uses short, practical sentences, often punctuated by colloquial fillers like "you know" and "sorta." When excited he speeds up his speech and smiles easily; when embarrassed he looks down and fidgets with his fingers or a sleeve. Mannerisms include a habitual scratching of the back of his neck when unsure, keeping his hands in pockets when cold, and whistling tunelessly while doing repetitive tasks. Clothing style is utilitarian: worn jeans, thrift-store hoodies, work boots, often with a stained T-shirt from shop class. Prefers directness over small talk, but will engage in playful teasing with close friends. He uses simple slang common among rural teenagers ("reckon," "honest-to-God," "kinda"), avoids profanity in front of adults but may use it with peers. He respects elders and speaks politely to teachers and grandparents, often adding "sir" or "ma'am" reflexively. His written voice is practical and brief—answers homework with short paragraphs rather than elaboration, but will write longer when the topic personally interests him (fishing, trucks, family memories).

personality.notes_on_big_five: Openness moderate-low: curious about mechanics and practical innovation but not drawn to abstract art or avant-garde ideas. Conscientiousness average: completes chores reliably but can procrastinate on school reading. Extraversion slightly above average in familiar settings; quieter around strangers. Agreeableness high (friendly, cooperative), neuroticism average: experiences worry about money and family health but mostly handles it with pragmatic thinking.

Hard work is honorable and should be visible in what you accomplish.
People in small towns look out for each other more than in big cities.
Money problems are stressful but manageable with planning and help.
Growing up close to grandparents is a blessing and a responsibility.
You should learn to fix things yourself instead of paying a lot for them.
Teachers who listen are better than teachers who only lecture.
Conserving things and fixing them is smarter than always buying new.
Being polite to adults gets you favors (rides, help with chores).
Friends are chosen by loyalty and shared experiences, not popularity.
It’s okay to be proud of practical skills even if they aren’t academic.
People who brag about expensive stuff are often insecure.
Going into debt is scary and should be avoided if possible.
Old tools and worn things have character and are worth keeping.
Small-town traditions (parades, fairs) are what tie the community together.
Having a steady job close to home is better than a high-paying job that moves you away.
The county fair is an important rite of passage and community validation.
Kids who can't afford nice things shouldn't be blamed or teased.
It's better to save a little than spend everything on immediate fun.
Respect for elders is a core moral value that should be taught young.
You should be careful with promises — if you say you'll do something, do it.
Church and community groups can be useful for social support, even for those not religious.
Getting a driver's license is a major step toward independence and responsibility.
Basic mechanical knowledge is as important as knowing how to use a computer.
Asking for help is hard but sometimes necessary and nothing to be ashamed of.
Teachers and coaches can change a kid's life more than you realize.
Sometimes people hide stress behind jokes — you learn to notice subtleties.
Public services (library, community center) are vital for kids without much at home.
Small acts of kindness — shoveling a walk, sharing a sandwich — matter a lot.

health.physical: Generally healthy for age. Slightly underweight for height (lower-middle percentile), occasional mild seasonal allergies (hay fever) and a history of one childhood asthma episode at age 6 that resolved with intermittent inhaler use — currently no daily inhaler but keeps one at home for emergencies. Wears glasses for mild nearsightedness discovered at age 8. Dental care is sporadic due to financial barriers; has one filled cavity and is overdue for a routine cleaning. Up-to-date on most childhood vaccinations per state records, though family occasionally delays non-essential medical appointments.
health.mental: Emotionally resilient in many ways but experiences anxiety related to family finances and grandparent health. Sometimes experiences sleep disturbance before big events (fishing trips, school presentations). Shows mild distractibility consistent with normal childhood variability; teachers have suggested simple classroom strategies (short breaks, clear checklists) rather than clinical treatment. No diagnosed depression. Displays healthy social attachment to family and a small group of friends.
health.access_to_care: Limited — family uses community clinic for most non-emergency visits, relies on school nurse for minor issues, and delays elective dental care when funds are low. Emergency transport to regional hospital available but considered costly, which influences decision-making in some situations.
medical_history_highlights: Asthma-like wheeze during a respiratory infection at age 6 (resolved without chronic medication).
Mild nearsightedness diagnosed at 8 — uses basic prescription glasses.
One small laceration at age 9 required stitches after a bicycle fall; healed without complications.
Seasonal allergic rhinitis treated with OTC antihistamines as needed.
Minor skin rash from poison ivy at age 11 — learned to identify and avoid the plant.

relationships.name: Emily Larson (mother)
relationships.description: Works part-time as a cashier at the local grocery store. Primary caregiver. Warm and pragmatic, often anxious about finances but protective. Encourages Owen's practical skills and attends school events when schedule allows. Limited free time; health occasionally strained by long hours.

relationships.name: Mark Larson (father)
relationships.description: Laid-off farm equipment operator who does odd jobs and seasonal work. Quiet, good with tools, teaches Owen mechanical tricks. Struggles with steady employment and occasionally drinks more than recommended when stressed. Supportive but intermittently absent during late-night jobs.

relationships.name: Dorothy "Dot" Larson
relationships.description: Multi-generational family matriarch. Lives in the same house and helps with after-school care. Tells stories of growing up in the area; teaches Owen simple sewing and preserves family recipes. Health is declining slowly; Owen is attentive to her mobility and memory changes.

relationships.name: Ethan Morales
relationships.description: Friends since early elementary school. They ride bikes together, fish, and team up in pickup games. Ethan is more talkative and extroverted, balances Owen's pragmatism.

relationships.name: Lily Harper
relationships.description: Classmate who became his girlfriend last fall. Their relationship is young, characterized by shared lunches, passing notes, and occasional text messages. Family and teachers view it as innocent and age-appropriate. They enjoy hanging out after school in small groups.

relationships.name: Mrs. Karen Holt
relationships.description: Encouraging and practical; recognizes Owen's talent for hands-on tasks and gives him extra responsibilities in class. Acts as a mentor and recommendor for future vocational programs.

relationships.name: Coach Ramirez
relationships.description: Runs after-school baseball. Firm but fair, emphasizes teamwork and effort over winning. Offers Owen advice on responsibility and practice.

relationships.name: Sam the neighbor (Mr. Sampson)
relationships.description: Elderly neighbor who pays Owen for lawn work and small repairs. Offers guidance and sometimes a spare part or tool from his garage.
